verses.text: Hear the word of the LORD, people of Israel! For the LORD has a case against those who live in the land: There is no truth, no lovingkindness, and no knowledge of God in the land.
verses.comment: Hosea opens this chapter much like a prophet calling a law court convened by God against Israel. The lack of 'truth', 'steadfast love', and 'knowledge of God' are central to Israel's sin. 'Knowledge of God' points not just to intellectual awareness, but to deep, covenantal relationship. Compare with Jeremiah 4:22. The call to a faithful knowledge of God anticipates the New Covenant promises of Jeremiah 31:33-34, where God's law will be written on the heart.

verses.text: There is only cursing, lying, murder, stealing, and adultery; they break all bounds, and bloodshed follows bloodshed.
verses.comment: This verse echoes the Ten Commandments, listing violations to highlight the moral collapse of society. The phrase 'bloodshed follows bloodshed' implies generational cycles of violence.

verses.text: Therefore the land mourns, and all who live in it waste away, along with the beasts of the field, the birds of the sky, and even the fish of the sea are taken away.
verses.comment: Here sin does not just impact humans—it brings suffering to all creation, pointing to the interconnectedness of moral order and the natural world. This theme anticipates the teaching in Romans 8:22 regarding creation groaning for redemption.

verses.text: Yet let no one contend, and let none accuse, for your people are like those who contend with the priest.
verses.comment: To 'contend with the priest' refers to rebelling against spiritual authority. The priesthood here is seen as a God-given mediator for the people, reflecting a broader pattern of God's order for worship and guidance.

verses.text: You will stumble by day, and the prophet also will stumble with you by night; and I will destroy your mother.
verses.comment: 'Mother' likely refers to the nation of Israel, the collective people. The prophets and priests (religious authorities) are not exempt from judgment; even spiritual leaders fall.

verses.text: My people are destroyed for lack of knowledge. Because you have rejected knowledge, I also reject you as my priests. Since you have forgotten the law of your God, I will forget your children.
verses.comment: Rejection of true knowledge—personal, covenantal relationship and adherence to God's revelation—leads to destruction. The idea of priesthood for the people connects to Exodus 19:6 and 1 Peter 2:9. Note the severe consequences for forgetting God's law, which underscores the importance of faithful transmission and teaching of truth.

verses.text: The more they increased, the more they sinned against me; I will change their glory into shame.
verses.comment: When prosperity led to pride and sin, their 'glory' (status as chosen people or possibly their priestly garments) is turned into shame, a reversal reminiscent of Romans 1:23 where glory is exchanged for shameful images.

verses.text: They feed on the sin offerings of my people and set their heart on their iniquity.
verses.comment: Priests not only tolerate the people's sin, but profit from it materially, evidence of religious corruption. True spiritual leadership seeks conversion, not self-gain.

verses.text: And it will be, like people, like priest; I will punish them for their ways and repay them for their deeds.
verses.comment: God holds both laypeople and priests accountable. Spiritual leaders and the people together bear responsibility for the nation's spiritual health.

verses.text: They will eat, but not have enough; they will play the prostitute, but not increase, because they have stopped paying attention to the LORD.
verses.comment: God reverses their blessings; disobedience brings futility. 'Prostitution' here is a metaphor for spiritual unfaithfulness, seen throughout Hosea.

verses.text: Prostitution, wine, and new wine take away understanding.
verses.comment: 'Understanding' is the wisdom that comes from walking with God. Here, indulgence in pleasure clouds discernment—echoing wisdom literature in Proverbs.

verses.text: My people consult their wooden idols, and their divining rods answer them. For a spirit of prostitution leads them astray, and they have been unfaithful to their God.
verses.comment: Idolatry is a recurring spiritual adultery in the Old Testament. The use of 'divining rods' points to pagan religious practices. True revelation comes only from God, not man-made means.

verses.text: They sacrifice on the tops of mountains and burn offerings on the hills, under oaks, poplars, and terebinths, where the shade is pleasant. Therefore your daughters play the prostitute, and your daughters-in-law commit adultery.
verses.comment: 'High places' were often locations of syncretistic pagan worship, forbidden by God's law (see Deut. 12:2-4). Spiritual unfaithfulness leads to moral and social corruption.

verses.text: I will not punish your daughters when they play the prostitute, nor your daughters-in-law when they commit adultery, for the men themselves go off with prostitutes and offer sacrifices with temple prostitutes. So a people without understanding will come to ruin.
verses.comment: The men’s guilt is emphasized as they are complicit in and enable immorality, especially through idolatrous temple practices. Spiritual blindness leads to national catastrophe.

verses.text: Though you, Israel, play the prostitute, let Judah not become guilty! Do not go to Gilgal, or up to Beth-aven, and do not swear, 'As the LORD lives!'
verses.comment: Beth-aven ('house of wickedness') is a pun on Bethel, the site of idolatrous worship. Gilgal was also corrupted. Hosea urges Judah not to repeat Israel's sins.

verses.text: For Israel is stubborn like a stubborn heifer. Can the LORD now feed them like a lamb in a broad pasture?
verses.comment: God contrasts Israel’s hard-heartedness with the humility He seeks. The shepherd imagery foreshadows Jesus as the Good Shepherd (John 10:11), who seeks and saves His people.

verses.text: Ephraim is joined to idols; leave him alone.
verses.comment: Ephraim often stands for the Northern Kingdom. Persistent idolatry leads to being given over to sin, similar to the 'handing over' described in Romans 1:24.

verses.text: When their drinking is over, they continue to give themselves to prostitution. Their rulers love shameful ways.
verses.comment: Leadership sets the tone for national morality. Persistent sin—even after sobering up—shows deep-rooted rebellion.

verses.text: A wind will carry them away in its wings, and they will be put to shame because of their sacrifices.
verses.comment: The 'wind' is a symbol of judgment and exile. The shame resulting from false worship recalls the biblical theme that true worship in spirit and truth (see John 4:23-24) brings dignity and life.
